note.p: Ridgley C. Powers served as governor of Mississippi from 1871 to 1874.

Born in Mecca, Ohio, on December 24, 1836, Powers was raised and educated in the north. In 1862, after receiving a degree from the University of Michigan, and conducting graduate work at Union College in New York, Powers enlisted in the Union Army for service during the Civil War. He was promoted to second lieutenant and then captain in the 125th Ohio Infantry Regiment and saw action in Tennessee and Georgia. By the time the Civil War ended in 1865, Powers had achieved the rank of colonel.

Upon separating from the military, Powers settled in Mississippi. He purchased land and began a cotton plantation. He soon became a public figure, serving as sheriff in Noxubee County. By 1868, Powers had gained status in Mississippi’s Republican Party, and was elected lieutenant governor in 1869. Although he was a “carpet bagger” (northerner who settled in the south during Reconstruction), Powers was generally respected by white Mississippians. This was in contrast to Governor James Alcorn, a northern by birth, but who was considered a “scalawag” since he had lived in Mississippi since the 1840s and had served in the Confederacy before joining the Republican Party. When Alcorn resigned the governor’s office in 1871 to take a seat in the U.S. Senate, Powers assumed the state’s executive office. He became active in promoting Mississippi’s economic development and independence, advocating crop variety and lesser dependence upon imported goods. Despite his efforts to maintain a stable political and economic environment in Mississippi, a rift grew among Republicans that led to competing party nominations for governor in 1873. Alcorn was nominated by the more conservative wing of Republicans against Adelbert Ames, former Union general and military governor, who was backed by the radicals. Ames won the election and took the governor’s seat in 1874.

In 1875, shortly after leaving office, Powers married Louisa Born. The couple had one child who died in infancy. They moved to Arizona, but Louisa suffered from a mysterious medical condition and began traveling across the United States and Europe for treatment. She passed away in New York in 1882 after undergoing surgery. Powers later remarried (to Mary Wilson) and moved to California. He spent the rest of his life as a rancher and businessman at Los Angeles. He died on November 11, 1912, and is buried in Angelus Rosedale Cemetery in Los Angeles, California.
(Wikipedia; Mississippi Encyclopedia; FindaGrave)

note.p: James L. Alcorn served as governor and then U.S. senator for Mississippi in the 1870s.

Born November 4, 1816, in Illinois Territory, Alcorn spent much of his young adulthood in Kentucky. After attending Cumberland College in Princeton, Kentucky, Alcorn was deputy sheriff of Livingston County, Kentucky, and then entered legal practice in the state in the 1830s. He served a short stint in the Kentucky House of Representatives in the early 1840s and then relocated to Mississippi, where he practiced law in Coahoma County. Financial success as an attorney enabled Alcorn to buy land and establish Mound Place Plantation in the Mississippi Delta region. By 1860, Alcorn owned nearly one hundred slaves; his land holdings alone were valued at approximately $9.5 million in today’s currency. Alcorn married Mary C. Stewart of Kentucky in 1839. The couple had five children before Mary passed away in 1849. Alcorn married Amelia Walton Glover of Alabama in 1850. He fathered three children with his second wife.

Alcorn was a Unionist during the 1850s. He served as a delegate to a special Mississippi convention to debate the south’s response to the Compromise of 1850—legislation passed in the U.S. Congress designed to settle a fierce dispute over the fate of slavery in territories gained by the United States from Mexico. He warned that secession would lead to war, with federal soldiers invading the south, liberating slaves, and a destroying southern society. Alcorn and other Unionists carried the day during the 1851 convention.

During the 1850s, Alcorn served in the Mississippi House of Representatives and Senate as a Whig. He led a legislative effort to establish levees to reduce flooding in the Delta region, and was elected the first president of the levee board. As his standing in Mississippi politics increased, he ran for election to U.S. Congress in 1856 but lost. Whigs in Mississippi subsequently considered him for a gubernatorial run in 1857, but Alcorn turned it down.

During the secession crisis following Abraham Lincoln’s election to the U.S. presidency in 1860, Alcorn initially maintained his Unionist leanings. However, when Mississippi issued its ordnance of secession, Alcorn pledged his loyalty to the state and volunteered for military service in Mississippi. He received an appointment as brigadier general for the state militia in 1861, but his military advancement was hindered by powerful political rivals. Alcorn led a brigade of three Mississippi militia regiments into the field in October 1861. His brigade spent three months Kentucky—experiencing miserable weather and mud, but no combat—before disbanding in January 1862 when their enlistments expired.

Alcorn returned home from Kentucky embittered and embroiled in disputes with his personal and political rivals. Although he backed Mississippi following secession, Alcorn was not particularly committed to the Confederate cause. After federal soldiers entered Mississippi in 1862, his plantation was among those raided. However, Alcorn established contacts within the Union army and began trading cotton with federal authorities against Confederate policy. As a result, his wealth grew and his plantation was spared the same level of destruction meted out to notable secessionists.

Alcorn reentered Mississippi politics immediately upon the defeat of the Confederacy. He was elected to the U.S. Senate in 1865 by the postwar Mississippi government’s effort to earn readmission into the Union under President Andrew Johnson’s lenient Reconstruction plan. However, the Mississippi legislature passed a series of highly discriminatory laws (known as the Black Codes) against recently emancipated African Americans, prompting Republicans in the United States Congress to refuse Mississippi back into the Union. As a result, Alcorn was denied his seat in the Senate.

Alcorn became a leading member of the Republican Party in Mississippi as Reconstruction developed. He embraced Black civil rights, including African American suffrage. Although born in the north, his long residency in, and service to, Mississippi before and during the Civil War made him a “scalawag” (white southerner who joined the Republican Party) to conservative whites in the south. Nevertheless, he gained enough political support to win the Republican nomination for governor and then the gubernatorial election in 1869 as Mississippi reentered the Union. He entered office in 1870 and oversaw the development of a state public education system, the creation of a land-grant college for African Americans (named Alcorn University in his honor), and pro-business acts to improve economic development in the state.

Alcorn resigned as governor in 1871 to take a seat in the U.S. Senate for Mississippi. Though still a Republican, Alcorn represented a more conservative side of the party. Though supporting Black civil rights, he resisted some federal intervention in Mississippi affairs, and generally held white supremacist views. This put him in opposition to the other senator from Mississippi, Adelbert Ames, a former Union general who had served as a military governor in Reconstruction Mississippi and led the more radical faction of Republicans in Mississippi that pushed total racial equality. Alcorn and Ames ran against each other for governor of Mississippi in 1873. Ames won by carrying most African American votes.

Alcorn left the U.S. Senate in 1877 and returned to Mississippi. He did not take part in most state political matters, but did stay active in the levee system and governing. In 1890, he was selected to be a delegate to the Mississippi constitutional convention. He was among the delegates the supported new restrictions against Black Mississippi rights. Alcorn died on December 19, 1894. He is buried in Friars Point, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; Timothy B. Smith, Mississippi in the Civil War, 134-135; David Sansing, “James Lusk Alcorn: Twenty-eighth Governor of Mississippi: March 180 to November 1871,” Mississippi History Now)

Alexander Gallatin McNutt was a lawyer, politician, writer, and Governor of Mississippi from 1838 to 1842. Born on January 3, 1802 in Rockbridge County, Virginia, McNutt moved to Jackson and then Vicksburg, Mississippi in the early 1820s where he practiced law. Following the murder of his partner Joel Cameron, McNutt married Elizabeth Ann (Lewis) (Cameron) in 1834. The two do not appear to have had any children. McNutt was also accused of instigating some of Cameron's enslaved men to commit the murder but was never charged. In the 1830s, McNutt became active as a politician. He was elected into the Mississippi state senate in 1835 and was elected Governor of Mississippi in 1837, serving two terms. After leaving office, he returned to his law practice and unsuccessfully ran for the United States Senate. McNutt died on October 22, 1848 in DeSoto County, Mississippi. He is buried in the Greenwood Cemetery in Jackson, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; Mississippi Encylopedia; FindaGrave; The Weekly Mississippian, April 23, 1845)

note.p: Albert Gallatin Brown was governor of Mississippi, a U.S. congressman and senator from Mississippi, and a member of the Confederate Senate. Born on May 31, 1813, in South Carolina, Brown moved with his family to Mississippi in 1823. Over the course of ten years, Brown’s family established a cotton plantation that contained 1,600 acres of land and 23 slaves. He attended Mississippi College and Jefferson College, and studied law to become a practicing attorney in 1834. A year later, he entered politics, winning a seat in Mississippi’s House of Representatives in 1835 and then serving in the U.S. House of Representatives from 1839 to 1841. He was a judge in Mississippi’s Circuit Superior Court from 1842 to 1843 and then, at the age of 31, won Mississippi’s gubernatorial election in 1843 as a Democrat. Brown was a staunch advocate of public education and successfully established the University of Mississippi, which opened in 1848.

Brown left the governor’s mansion in 1848 and returned to the U.S. House of Representatives. He served there until winning a seat in the U.S. Senate in 1854. He was an outspoken defender of slavery in Washington, D.C., in the latter half of the 1850s, even advocating the expansion of American slavery to Central America. When Mississippi seceded in 1861, following Abraham Lincoln’s election to the presidency, Brown resigned his seat in the Senate and returned to Mississippi to organize a militia company. He led his unit to Virginia, but was shortly afterwards elected to represent Mississippi in the Confederate Senate. He remained a member there until the end of the war.

Brown was among a small number of Confederate officials who foresaw the fall of the Confederacy in the wake of the battlefield defeats at Gettysburg and Vicksburg. He unsuccessfully recommended a negotiated settlement with the Union. When the war ended in 1865, Brown took a more reconciliatory stance to Reconstruction than many other former Confederates, recommending that the south accept emancipation. Despite having a political career during a controversial and dangerous period in American history, Brown was described as being among the most amicable and fair public figures, refusing to castigate or criticize his political opponents.

After the Civil War, Brown left public life. He practiced law in Mississippi for the next fifteen years. Brown was married twice during his life, first to Elizabeth Frances Thornton Taliaferro, who died less than a year after their wedding. His second wife was Roberta Eugenia Young. The couple had one child.
Brown died of a stroke on June 12, 1880, at home in Mississippi. He is buried in Greenwood Cemetery in Jackson, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; National Governors Association; David Sansing, “Albert Gallatin Brown: Fourteenth Governor of Mississippi: 1844-1848,” Mississippi History Now)

John Jones McRae was a lawyer and statesman from Mississippi who served in the Mississippi House of Representatives, the U.S. Senate, the U.S. House of Representatives, as the 21st Governor of Mississippi, and the Confederate Congress.

McRae was born on January 10, 1815 in Sneedsboro (present-day McFarlan), Anson County, North Carolina. At age two, his family moved to Winchester, Wayne County, Mississippi in 1817 and later to Pascagoula, Jackson County, Mississippi in 1827. He attended the University of Miami in Ohio, graduating in 1834. McRae returned to Mississippi to study law at Pearlington. He was admitted to the bar in 1835 and began practicing law in Paulding, Mississippi. In October 1835 he married Mary Annette McGuire, and the couple had three children together. He founded the newspaper Eastern Clarion in 1837.

McRae’s political career began when he was elected as a Democrat to the Mississippi House of Representatives in 1847, serving as Speaker of the House in 1850. He was appointed to the United States Senate from December 19, 1851 until March 17, 1852 to serve the remainder of Jefferson Davis’s unexpired term when he resigned to run for Governor of Mississippi.

In 1853 McRae was elected as the 21st Governor of Mississippi under the Democratic States’ Rights platform. He was reelected in 1855. During his time in the Governorship McRae’s administration oversaw the opening of the state’s first mental hospital and established an asylum for the deaf and speechless. He also oversaw the State’s levy program in the Delta and signed the Mississippi Code of 1857 into law. McRae was elected to the United States House of Representatives in 1858 following the death of Congressman John A. Quitman. He served in Congress until January 12, 1861, resigning his seat three days after Mississippi seceded from the Union. He was elected to the Confederate Congress and served from 1862 to 1864.

McRae was not involved in public affairs after the Civil War. His wife Mary died in 1866. In 1868 he sailed to Belize (present-day Belize City), British Honduras (Present-day Belize) to visit his brother. While there he died unexpectedly on May 31, 1868. He is buried at Lord Ridge Cemetery, Belize City, Belize.
(United States Congress, Biographical Directory of the United States Congress; Mississippi Department of Archives and History; NCpedia; FamilySearch; FindaGrave; Wikipedia)

Located in north-central Mississippi, Chickasaw County was established on March 1, 1836 from Monroe County. (Mississippi Encyclopedia; Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

Located between Maryland & Virginia on the Potomac River, the Territory of Columbia was established on July 16, 1790 under the name Federal City and was renamed Washington City in the 1800s. The city of Washington became the federal capital on February 27, 1801 and established as Washington, D.C. on February 24, 1801, when the city boundaries were expanded to include the entire Federal District of Columbia. Washington, D.C. has never achieved statehood. (Wikipedia, Britannica)
Located in Lafayette County, Oxford was founded in 1837 and serves as the county seat. (Wikipedia)

Located in Adams County, Natchez was founded in 1716 under the name Fort Rosalie and was renamed Natchez in 1730. It became part of the newly created Adams County on April 1, 1799. It served as the capital of Mississippi Territory from 1798 until 1802, when it was replaced by Washington. It was reinstated as the capital from 1817 until 1820, when the capital was again replaced by Washington (which was later replaced by the current capital Jackson in 1822). Natchez serves as the county seat. (Wikipedia; Britannica; Mississippi Encyclopedia)

In the early 1800s, Mississippi chartered its banks to meet the needs of the quickly growing cotton industry. This included setting up branches, which was an innovative idea at the time. There was resistance to a national bank, and Mississippi had insufficient banking infrastructure for its booming cotton economy. In the 1830s, the state relaxed its banking regulations and chartered many new banks quickly, leading to speculation and risky lending practices. This, along with federal policies, contributed to the Panic of 1837. Mississippi even resorted to issuing unconstitutional bonds to fund a bank, Union Bank, which ultimately failed. The state's credit was ruined. The Civil War devastated Mississippi's banking system. Due to the war and the shift from a slave-based to a free-labor economy, existing banks collapsed or became unreliable. The National Banking Acts of 1863 and 1864, which established a national banking system, offered little help to Mississippi as the high capital requirements for these banks made them inaccessible to the state. Local merchants filled the gap by offering credit to planters based on the cotton crop. The number of banks grew rapidly in the late 19th century, largely due to out-of-state funds from northern banks and financial houses. The Mississippi Bankers Association was formed in 1889 to promote responsible banking practices. ("Banking," Mississippi Encyclopedia)

The United States Constitution was ratified in 1788 as the foundational code of laws for the United States of America. It was crafted in 1787 by a convention in Philadelphia originally tasked only with amending the existing Articles of Confederation, which had loosely combined the states under a weak central government. Delegates chose to set aside the articles entirely and create a stronger federal government made of three branches: the legislative (comprising two separate parts, the House of Representatives and the Senate), the judicial (led by the Supreme Court), and the executive (headed by the President of the United States). The Constitution sought to carefully balance competing interests regarding state and national authority, as well as large and small state representation. It also created a more direct relationship between Americans and the national government.

The convention’s departure from its original mandate to amend the Articles of Confederation generated controversy, particularly among Americans who opposed placing a distant central authority of the states. The Constitution’s supporters advocated the need for a stronger national government and explained that the federal system preserved state authority for most local matters. To guarantee enough support for ratification, the Constitution’s supporters agreed to add an addendum to more directly protect individuals' specific rights and freedoms. The Constitution was ratified in 1788 and the new United States government began in early 1789. Shortly afterwards, the new Congress adopted several amendments to the Constitution, ten of which were ratified by three-fourths of the states and became known as the Bill of Rights. These first ten amendments guaranteed certain rights for American citizens. Since then, seventeen additional amendments have been ratified to the United States Constitution. Three of them—the Thirteenth, Fourteenth, and Fifteenth Amendments—were adopted between 1865 and 1870, during the Reconstruction Era. The Thirteenth Amendment formally abolished slavery. The Fourteenth Amendment provides equal protection for all laws and the Fifteenth Amendment protects voting rights for American citizens regardless of “race, color, or previous condition of servitude,” both specifically to combat racial discrimination against African Americans following the end of slavery. (Wikipedia; National Archives and Records Administration)

Ratified in 1870, the Fifteenth Amendment prohibits the federal and state governments from denying a citizen’s right to vote according to race, skin color, or previous condition of servitude. It was the third, and last, of the Reconstruction amendments.

The Thirteenth Amendment, ratified in 1865, formally abolished slavery in the United States. That amendment, as well as the Fourteenth Amendment—which was ratified in 1868 and guaranteed citizenship and equal protect of people regardless of race—did not directly protect Black voting rights. While Black citizens in some states and territories did enjoy the right to vote, millions of African Americans in former slave states were barred from the ballot box. To better ensure suffrage among African Americans across the country, Republicans passed the Civil Rights Act of 1866. However, President Andrew Johnson had vetoed the Civil Rights Act. Although Congress overrode the veto, opposition to the bill and doubts by even some of its supporters that the act would survive judicial review led to an effort to protect Black voting with a Constitutional amendment.

Initial language for the Fifteenth Amendment protected a far larger set of factors, including race, color, nativity, property, education, and religious beliefs. This was pared down by nativist representatives, especially from the north, from districts with strong anti-immigrant sentiments, and some Republican officials who feared that such a sweeping protection of voting rights could enable former Confederates to regain voting rights far more quickly than Reconstruction policies allowed. The final text also made no mention of certain voting restrictions, such as poll taxes and literacy tests, used by conservative white officials in the south to restrict Black voting. The Fifteenth Amendment also did not explicitly protect the right of African Americans to run for political office.

Resistance to the Fifteenth Amendment’s ratification also came from some female suffragists. Before the Civil War, many women’s rights advocates worked alongside abolitionists for equal rights. Some women objected to the amendment’s emphasis on voting rights according to race without similar protections for women. This argument even split some female rights groups among those who supported the amendment and those who opposed it.

Many western, New England, and deep south states ratified the Fifteenth Amendment shortly after its passage through Congress in 1869. New England had been the traditional home of progressive social movements like abolitionism and suffrage, and the deep south was still largely controlled by Republican officials for Reconstruction. The amendment went into effect after Iowa ratified it in February 1870. Most of the last states to ratify it were the former border states during the Civil War—which had largely conservative state governments and were not under federal control during Reconstruction. (Wikipedia)

Located in Lorman, Mississippi, Alcorn State University was established in 1871 as an agricultural and mechanical institution. It is also known as a public land-grant historically Black college. (Wikipedia)

Located in Oxford, Mississippi, the University of Mississippi was established on February 24, 1844 as a public research institute. It operated as a Confederate Hospital during the American Civil War and is Mississippi's oldest public university. (Wikipedia)

Located in Raliegh, North Carolina, Shaw University (formerly known as Raleigh Theological Institute) was established on December 1, 1865 as a private Black university in affiliation with the American Baptist Churches (USA). (Wikipedia)

Operating at the national level, the United States Congress was founded in 1789 as a part of the legislative branch of the nation's federal government. It is comprised of the Senate and the House of Representatives, both of whom are responsible for creating and passing bills and convene at the State's Capitol located in Washington, D.C. Members can be elected to serve repeatedly and must be at least twenty-five years of age for the House of Representatives and at least thirty for the Senate. They must also reside in the state in which they represent and have United States Citizenship for at least seven years for the House of Representatives or nine years for the Senate. (Wikipedia)

Operating at the state level, the Executive Department of the State of Mississippi consists of the governor, lieutenant governor, secretary of state, state treasurer, state comptroller, commissioner of agriculture, commissioner of insurance, the Mississippi Public Service Commission, the Mississippi Transportation Commission, and attorney general. Each official is elected for a four-year term and is appointed duties pertaining to state regulations. (Wikipedia)

Operating at the state level, the Mississippi State Legislature (originally called the "General Assembly") was established by Article 4 of the Mississippi Constitution on November 1, 1890, and serves as the legislative branch of the state government. It is comprised of the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Legislature is responsible for passing new statewide laws and making amendments to the Constitution. (Wikipedia)

Operating at the state level, the Mississippi House of Representatives was established by Article 4 of the Mississippi Constitution on November 1, 1890, and serves as the lower house of the Mississippi Legislature. It is led by the Speaker of the House and is responsible for drafting new statewide laws and has the power to impeach officials. (Wikipedia)

Operating at the state level, the Mississippi Senate was established by Article 4 of the Mississippi State Constitution on November 1, 1890, and serves as the upper house of the Mississippi Legislature. It is led by the Senate President and is responsible for drafting new statewide laws and conducting trials of impeachment. (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: Formed in 1817 and operating at the state level, the Mississippi Secretary of State is elected by the state for a four-year term and is responsible for overseeing state election laws and government records. The seat is located in Jackson, Mississippi. (Wikipedia)

Operating at the state level, the Mississippi State Treasurer's office was created in 1817 in Jackson when the state was admitted to the Union. The State Legislature appointed the State Treasurer until 1832 when the Treasurer became popularly elected to serve a two-year term (changed to four years in 1869). The State Treasurer is responsible for overseeing and maintaining Mississippi's financial records. (Wikipedia)

In the United States in the nineteenth century, most college students, with few exceptions, were white males from elite families. Few universities admitted women or African Americans. The nation's earliest universities were established by Christian denominations, but college education, however, often served as much to provide social and cultural capital for aspiring social elites as much as practical knowledge (Roger L. Geiger, The History of American Higher Education, 267). From their findings throughout the seventeenth, eighteenth, and nineteenth centuries, American universities exposed college students primarily to classical liberal arts curricula, including classical languages, logic, and the natural sciences, though that education expanded to broader subjects throughout the nineteenth century.

Many colleges and universities, especially but not exclusively in the South, built their schools and supported their white student populations with enslaved labor. In many universities in slave states, students brought enslaved persons with them to universities. American colleges and universities, as well as their students, therefore profited from the enslaved labor of African Americans while institutionalizing educational and wealth inequality between white and Black Americans as well as between men and women of both races. However, other colleges, such as Oberlin College in Ohio, admitted women and African Americans even in the antebellum period.

In 1862, the Morrill Land Grant Act set aside federal property to be used to establish colleges devoted to agricultural and mechanical studies, broadening both the student population and curriculum of American universities. After Emancipation, many African Americans established colleges and universities across the nation, now known as Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU) to increase Black Americans' access to higher education, though the full integration of higher education in the nation would not come until a century later during the Civil Rights Movement of the 1960s (Roger L. Geiger, The History of American Higher Education; Wikipedia).

gloss.p: Historically free African Americans included people who were both African American and lived as and/or were legally free before the American Civil War. They may or may not have previously been enslaved. In recognition of African American military service during the Revolutionary War, a number of states moved to gradually abolish slavery leading to a growing body of free African Americans.

Freedom, however, did not mean citizenship, and despite efforts by free Black activists to settle this question and affirm their citizenship, it was largely left to state lawmakers who otherwise failed to settle the question. Consequently, during the Antebellum era, each southern state passed different laws governing the place and rights of free African Americans. Home to the nation's largest free African American community, for example, Baltimore, Maryland registered 25,000 free Black residents by 1850. (Martha S. Jones, Birthright Citizens: A History of Race and Rights in Antebellum America, p. 13)

In another example, South Carolina's Act of 1820 distinguished between those freed before and after 1820, and classified free African Americans as "denizens," which limited citizenship rights by a series of Black Codes. In response to rebellions, numerous states passed legal restrictions that made manumission virtually impossible by the mid-nineteenth century. Loved ones who purchased family members were forced to legally hold them in bondage, leading to a body of people who "were free by practice, but not by law." (Amrita Chakrabarti Myers, Forging Freedom, 3–4, 207)

Unlike South Carolina, Mississippi's judiciary ruled that “free negroes . . . are to be regarded as alien enemies or strangers prohibited, and without the pale of comity, and incapable of acquiring or maintaining property in this State which will be recognized by our courts.” (Heirn v. Bridault, 37 Miss. 209, 224–25, 1859 in Jones, Birthright Citizens, p. 213) The state's strict provisions on manumission led to an extremely small population of free African Americans (773 people by 1860) during the antebellum era ("Free Blacks in Antebellum Mississippi," Mississippi Encyclopedia)

Newly freed African Americans includes people who were enslaved but became free by the passage of the Emancipation Proclamation and/or the Thirteenth Amendment. While neither was comprehensive, the Emancipation Proclamation of 1863 freed the enslaved in territories under rebellion, and later the Thirteenth Amendment of 1865 abolished slavery altogether, except when used as a punishment for those who committed a crime and did not apply to Native Nations who practices slavery. (American Battlefield Trust; Wikipedia) In the CWRGM collection, African Americans after December 6, 1865 are classified as historically free or newly freed.

Impoverished people are those who lack "a usual or socially acceptable amount of money or material possessions," or alternately those who "lack the means to satisfy their basic needs (Britannica). This definition, necessarily subjective and broad, indicates that what one person or society deems "socially acceptable" or what constitutes "basic needs" is malleable.

Similarly, impoverished people in the United States in the nineteenth century did not fit one specific category. The rise of industrialism produced an increased number of impoverished people in the U. S., particularly within large urban centers. European immigrants in cities in the East, and Chinese immigrants on the West Coast, and African Americans in the South were disproportionately affected by poverty. Regionally, the highest number of impoverished people came from the U. S. South, where "both whites and African Americans struggled with debt, low cotton prices, laws favorable to employers and creditors, paltry alternatives, and the general post war devastation" (Encyclopedia of the United States in the Nineteenth Century, Vol. 2, 547).

Racism and nativism among employers and employees also made economic advancement more difficult for people of color and immigrants. However, the impoverished made up a comparatively low percentage of Mississippi's antebellum population, given its low number of immigrants and even native residents, lack of industrialization and urbanization, and mobility of those that were impoverished (Mississippi Encyclopedia). Many reform organizations throughout the country took the lead in fighting poverty in the nineteenth century, while state and federal governments by the end of the century also developed its own institutional responses. The status of being impoverished has always carried negative connotations in American history, so CWRGM uses the tag "Impoverished people" to emphasize the personhood of those in poverty rather than their social status.

term.rs: African Americans--Historically Free and Newly Freed

gloss.p: A power of attorney is "the legal right to act for someone else in their financial or business matters, or the document that gives you this right" (Cambridge Dictionary). Power of attorney can be granted for numerous and varied reasons, generally to those whose relatives or legal dependents are deemed incapable of managing their own affairs due to disability, age, or other factors. Power of attorney privileges in the nineteenth-century United States most often had negative effects on women. American law placed men at the head of their households, and at marriage a woman's political and legal identity was subsumed into her husband's in a process known as "coverture." While not technically a power of attorney agreement, this arrangement provided the same practical powers and granted men full control of their wives' property, finances, and often, in the case of divorce, custody of children. Powers of attorney in the nineteenth-century U. S. therefore highlight the level of legally protected patriarchal authority exercised by men North and South (Encyclopedia of the United States in the Nineteenth Century, Vol.1, 533-537).

catDesc.note:
Categories:
Social Identifiers -- Races, Ethnicities, & Nationalities

gloss.p: The Cambridge Dictionary classifies "a person who lives in the U.S. and is a member of a race of people with dark skin that originally came from Africa" as African American, but both the nineteenth-century and modern constructions are more complex (Cambridge Dictionary). Common nineteenth-century racial categories such as "mulatto" referred to persons with both white and black ancestry, and the experiences of mixed-race persons varied based on complexion, degree of African ancestry, and the region in which they lived. In antebellum cities with large populations of free Blacks, the degree of one's African ancestry could determine what rights one possessed or did not possess, and people with lighter skin tones were often considered to be white; this ended under "one drop rule" during the Jim Crow system.

Like skin tone, the ethnicity implied by the term "African American" is also problematically broad, as "naming people only by the continent of their origin and ignoring their ethnic identity is a consequence of time and space" (Painter, Creating Black Americans, 5). The experience of slavery complicated the term by attempting to strip people of their original distinct African ethnic identities such as Ibo or Ndongan, classifying all persons of African descent together under one term, infusing that term with negative connotation, and disregarding the complex and rich linguistic, cultural, and ethnic histories of varied African people. However, many Black Americans have reclaimed the term "African American" and infused it with positive connotations. One scholar argues that "in using the term 'African Americans,' Black Americans accent the part of their heritage that is not American" (Painter, Creating Black Americans, 4).

CWRGM — acknowledging the multiplicity of the term's meanings and connotations — includes multiracial and multiethnic people of African descent under the "African Americans" social identifiers subject tag to reflect the diversity of the African American experience and to ensure that the experiences of African Americans of mixed races and ethnicities are discoverable as they are rarely distinguished further in the letters. In the absence of other references, CWRGM also tags racial slurs targeted at African Americans — which were common in nineteenth century documents with white authors — under the "African Americans" tag. CWRGM recognizes the historic and present harm caused by such language and does not condone its use but tags these terms only to ensure the rich history of African Americans are discoverable within the collection.

term.rs: African Americans--Historically Free and Newly Freed

gloss.p: While the Cambridge Dictionary defines death as “the end of life,” CWRGM employs this subject tag to refer to human deaths only, both actual and hypothetical. (Cambridge Dictionary)

The nation experienced mass loss of life (approximately 2% of the population) during the American Civil War, which changed the way Americans viewed death and resulted in its reconceptualization in highly bureaucratized ways. Often wartime dead were buried without their names and sometimes in poorly-dug graves, which created a powerful, profound social and cultural dislocation for their surviving loved ones. During the 19th century, Americans understood dying as a social and religious experience, and desired a "good death," which they defined as at home surrounded by family, but these ideals were unattainable in war. Consequently, Americans learned to cope with death and memorialize it in new ways. Unionists encouraged the federal government and ex-Confederates pushed their respective state governments to create and fund national cemeteries, rebury deceases soldiers and veterans, and establish veterans' and widows' pensions. These new responses to death were more bureaucratized, nationalistic, and secularized. Wartime and post-war death was also highly impacted by race, as white supremacists desecrated the graves of Union buried in the South, especially the bodies of African Americans who served in U.S. Colored Troops and the white officers that led them, revealing post-war sectionalism and strains on reconciliation. (Drew Gilpin Faust, This Republic of Suffering)

div.p: [note] 1871 [/note]
[note] May 1—1871 [/note]

To,
The Senate
and
House of Representatives
Gentlemen,

In my annual message submitted to your honorable bodies last January, I brought under your consideration a brief pro-position ^in brief^ for an expansion of the existing University and the establishment of a similar In-stitution for the education of negroes. I disposed of the subject then in the following remarks (pages 23 and 24 of my January message):

"The University of Oxford received last year a payment from the State to the amount of $38.551. The salaries of a full body of professors are barely covered by this expenditure; and we must be prepared, therefore, to deal here-after with the claim of the Institution upon us for a more considerable annuity. The number of students in the establishment now does not
[note] ion [/note]
justify even the present expenditure; and the question comes up thus whether we shall allow the University to go down, or take steps to extend its benefits to a greater number of our youths. x x x.

"The Literary Fund of the past had been dedicated to the education of the children of the poor. The old domination alienated it from that sacred purpose, in part by its investments in Bank Stocks and in part by the application of its revenues to the academies of the rich. The school lands which were granted to the State for the education of the masses of the people fell into the hands of the old règimé; and, like all the other public trusts of those days, have been the subject of spoilation. Under these circumstances the gathering up of the remnant of the school lands and the re-application of the revenues originally set apart for the Literary Fund do not make good the bad faith of the past to the masses.

of the children of Mississippi. As somewhat of a requital for the wrong done the children of the people by the men who controlled the affairs of the State from the time of its organization until the close of the late war, I propose that we fill out the opportunity presented in the University by bringing its advantages within the reach of the poor. With that purpose I recommend earnestly that you establish a system of scholarships in the University of two groups—one group free [?], another at half rate—and that one of each of these scholarships shall be given to the common schools of each County of the State as a prize to be won by the best answerers in a com-petitive examination. One hundred thousand dollars would be well applied in discharging this com-pensation to the masses of the people for the plunder of the funds de-dicated to their education; and while discharging a double duty—to beneficiaries of the common
school fund and to those of the University fund—will consecrate the memories of the University in the affections of the great body of the people.
x x x x

"Colored boys may be expected to present themselves within four or five years at the level of the curriculum of the High School, if not of the University. We ought not to be unprepared to discharge our obligations to them as we discharge it to white boys, by the time at which they shall have made their coming demand for a collegiate education. xxx. Whether the Shaw University or some Institution situated in some ^the^ Southern portion of the State shall be made the vehicle of University training for the negro youth, I am anxious that steps be taken to initiate the realization of that purpose, so as to throw out to the emulation of the colored boys of our public schools the same generous system of free & half free scholarships by which I hope to see the University of Oxford
placed, superior to all clashes of party or of race, a perpetual glory of the Mississippians of my own blood."

Before your adjournment, I invite your attention earnestly to the points touched on in the above remarks. Reflection on the re-commendations made above, have suggested to my mind revisions and additions under which I take leave to bring the whole subject before you in a fullness of specification that may strengthen your convictions of duty in the case, and simplify the work of its practical discharge.

The Congress of the United States granted, in an act approved February the 20th,, 1819, thirty—six sections of land for the endowment in this State of a "Seminary of Learning". These lands were, at first, placed under a system of leasing; and continued so for ten or twelve years with a net result to

the credit of the Seminary of $8,102.00. In 1831 an Act was passed ordering the sale of this valuable property on notes payable by instalments in one, two, and three, years. The sale was made in 1833. With the exception of half a section, the whole was disposed of in exchange for notes with "approved security" to the aggregate amount of $277.322.00.
Governor. Lynch states in his message of 1837, (Senate Journal page 54) "the bonds and notes given for the Seminary lands & which
[page torn]

20th,, 1819, thirty—six sections of land for the endorsement in this State of a "Seminary of Learning". These lands were, at first, placed under a system of leasing; and continued so for ten or twelve years with a net result to
[note] are [/note]
amount to $277.000.00 and ^are^ now all due; and the original sales, together with the interest that has accrued, now exceeds $310.000."—Such was the condition and amount of the fund in 1837.

Governor. McNutt shows the con-dition of the assets resulting from the sale of the Seminary land, in his message of January 8th,, 1859. He says on that subject (Senate Journal page 8.) "The Seminary fund now amounts to $314.146.00 exclusive of interest, and half a section of land,"

Auditor Saunders specifies the items of the Seminary fund in 1841. In his letter (printed on page 425 of the House Journal of that year) he states those items thus:—
Remaining uncollected$168.578
Invested in Planters Bank stock$129.300
Do, in Planters Bank of Natchez$7.889
Do Paid into State Treasury$16.439
Total$322.146 Under the terms of the Act of Congress making the grant, the Seminary lands were "vested in the Legislature of the said State in trust for the support of a

Seminary of Learning therein". A trust as this donation was, the State is bound to make good any and all losses resulting to that trust by her own maladministration.—Now that I have shown you the amount and condition of the fund at different periods previous to its utter wreck, let me point out, in brief, the justice with which that wreck must be held chargeable to the State's abuse of her office as a trustee.—

Governor McNutt says of the Seminary land—fund (Senate Journal of 1839 page 8): "The notes are generally well secured; but many of them are under protest. xxx The late Auditor, John N. Mallory, has embezzled a portion of the fund; and the best interests of the State require the immediate establish-ment of the Seminary. xx. Unless the University is speedily established, or the law providing for the collection of the fund changed, a large portion of it may be lost. Many of the drawers of the notes are dead; and others have re-moved out of the State".—Such was the development of the "State's management of the trust two years after all the
notes had become due,

A committee of the House of Representatives put the State's abuse of her trust, in the case of the Seminary lands, in evidence thus in 1841: "Your committee", says the report of that body on page 420—1 of the House Journal of 1841, "has not been informed of any great ex-ertion having been made to collect this large amount of debt; and from the best information they have on the subject, a great proportion of it is in a very bad condition on account of the insolvency of the debtors. They are con-strained to believe that, if due diligence had been used in the collection, more than three-fourths of this large outstanding debt could have been collected before this time."

A still broader confession of the abuse of the State's trust in the case is made by Auditor Saunders. That officer gives, on page 121 of House Journal of 1841, evidence of the malad-ministration of that trust thus: "In some instances the purchasers and securities are all dead; the land is occupied by persons who are not bound

for the payment of the same; and the timber is being destroyed and the land is wearing away. xx. In some instances there are no persons, either as principal, securities, executors, or administrators, on whom to serve a writ for the purpose of obtaining judgment." And the alientation of the Seminary land, allowed to go on under such a state of facts as these, has taken place in the face of a contract of sale making a redemption of the purchase notes a con-dition precedent to the transfer of the title!

Governor Brown referring to the Seminary fund says, in his message of January. 6. 1846: "The State is, in my opinion, under the most solemn obligation to pay it back". Governor McRae says in a copious message estimating the amount of the Seminary fund (page 29 House Journal of 1856): "which is at this time, the just endow-ment of the University from what the State has actually received or recognized as equivalent to money, by her executive officers, from the grant made to her in trust by Congress "for the support of a
[note] these [/note]

Seminary of learning"." And in ad-dition to the ^these^ confessions by her executive officers, of the liability of the State to the University, I, who am constrained by no tenderness for the old regimé which has made all the interests of the people since their organization under even a Territorial Government, subjects of persistent plunder, declare solemnly that, because of fraud shown unmistakably on the record, the State of Mississippi is liable in political morals for every dollar of the balance due ^to^ the Seminary Fund.

An Act of July 26 1843 confesses the liability of the State to the University by making it the duty of the Treasurer to set forth that liability in the form of a public account. It directs him "to credit the University fund with interest at the rate of five per cent, upon all monies theretofore paid into the Treasury from the time when so paid to the passage of this Act; and thereafter to annually credit said fund with interest at the rate of 8 per cent. per annum for all monies due from the State to said fund". Under the terms of

this clause a calculation was made showing (See message of Governor McRae page 290, House Journal of 1856) the gross liability of the State on account of the Seminary fund, to have been, on January 1st,, 1857, $1.077.790.

The estimate given by Governor McRae presents a certain looseness on its face. The debits are, for example; calculated up to 1857; whilst the credits are calculated up to 1856. The five per cent interest is reckoned on the whole principal of the fund; where-as the act confines it to "all monies theretofore paid into the Treasury", upwards of $168.000 of the fund having remained so late as 1841 unpaid. In addition to these objections to this estimate of Governor McRae, another law had intervened; for the Act of February 25th,, 1848 directed that, upon the sum "then standing on the ^books of the^ Treasurer of the State, and upon all sums, that may hereafter be paid into the Treasury of the State to the credit of the University," there should be paid a semi—annual interest of six per cent.

The State has failed in her obligations to the University under the Act of 1843; and under also the Act of 1848. With but $89.000 on the Treasurer's books subject today to six per cent interest in favor of the University, the current records themselves present no true measure of the liability of the State to that Institution. Rejecting the estimate of Governor McRae; rejecting the broken compacts made in the laws of 1843 and of 1848; rejecting the deficient aggregate of the amount shown on the Treasurer's books, the only true means of estimating the amount due by the State to the University is that of dealing with the principal, as in a similar case between individuals, on the basis of an interest of six per cent per annum—every payment calling for a fresh striking of the balance of the account.
Auditor Saunders states, as cited above, the amount of the Seminary fund in January 1841. He does so with a specification which shows accuracy. The account appears to have been kept
[note] be taken [/note]

up to that time with care. The figures of Auditor Saunders may, therefore, ^be taken^ as a faithworthy starting-point for estimating the amount due the Seminary fund today. On that basis,, calculating the interest at six per cent, and striking the balance due at every payment made, the amount which the State now owes the University is found by calculation to be about $650.000.

Governor Brown in his message of January 6, 1846 (See page 18, House Journal of 1846) estimates the School lands then in the hands of the town-ships at from ten to twelve hundred sections—about 700.000 acres. This munificent donation was ^like the subsequent donation of 176.000 acres to the Chickasaw district^ made in trust for the children of the State; and were ^was^ accepted by the State subject to all the responsibilities of a trustee.

Under the Act of February. 27. 1833, the short leases of the previous period were abandoned for the virtual alienation of the school lands authorizing the lease of those lands for 99 years. The leases under that act were to be made on notes payable in one, two, three,

Governor Brown gives the result of this legislation thus: He says he has "not been enabled to ascertain that over 100 of the 1100 sections have been well managed. Some of them" he adds "have been trespassed on and denuded of their timber; in other instances they have been leased and the money has not been collected; in many instances it has been collected and squandered; and in the fewest number of cases have there been free schools kept by the proceeds".

And, in fine, the splendid donation made by Congress for the education of the children of the poor of this State—a donation worth millions of dollars—may be declared, without any further proof from the record of a fact so notorious to all our people, to have been squandered after the fashion of all other trusts ^in the hands^ of Mississippi democracy, by a manage-ment of imbecility and fraud!
The colored people of the State bear no responsibility for the malad—

ministration of the old regimé. They are now, however, joint heirs of the then governing race in the bequests of the United States. The school—tax of the present day comes mainly from the pockets of the whites; and in that point of view rests on the footing of a just requital.

But the negro is ^But the negro is^ moving up rapidly to the position of a tax—payer; and may, therefore, begin to claim now special injury at the hands of the whites in the wicked ex-haustion, by the democracy, of the school resources of the State. I propose to compensate the colored people for that waste of their educational inheritance by the foundation of an institution for their education in the higher walks of learning. While, therefore, discharging the obligation of political morality to the University education of the whites, I recommend earnestly the discharge of the obligations of political morality to the University education of the blacks also.
The negroes are not yet sufficiently advanced for the establishment at this moment, of a negro—University. Our common

schools will, however, have given out before five years, colored boys in considerable numbers sufficiently advanced to enter the curriculum of the University. So soon, indeed, may this condition of things be looked for, that I propose to prepare for it at once; and, with that view, recommend earnestly the immediate establish-ment of a high school, so directed and cherished that it may keep pace with all the demands of the hour in a healthy progress to the level of the college. I recommend that you ap-propriate fifty thousand dollars for this purpose; that you place its management in the hands of a board of trustees acting under a President; and that the Board thus constituted have full power to purchase a site and buildings in the Southern part of the State; to locate and furnish the same; to employ teachers; and give shape to the future of the Institution—the appropriation to be continued for a period of ten years, provided that no greater sum shall be drawn than is found necessary to establish and
maintain the institution at the standard necessary to meet ^its proper^ the wants. of the same, all these duties to be discharged with the approval of the Governor.

At the rate of interest paid upon our Bonds, the amount due by the State to the University would represent an income of $50.000. I recommend that you declare that sum to be, henceforth, a fixed annuity payable semi—annually to that "Seminary of Learning". In consideration of the chemical apparatus and landed property already owned by the Oxford University, I submit respectfully that you assign to it but two—fifths of the proceeds of the land—scrip donated by Congress for the establishment of an agricultural college or colleges—conditioned, however, that the amount given to that University shall be applied under the direction of the Board of Trustees so as to give young men of this society of agriculturists, the benefit of education in the art and science of agriculture. I suggest that you apply to the establishment immediately of a similar professorship in the future University for the education of our youth of color.

When recently in ^the city of^ Washington City I arranged for the issuance of the agricultural College land scrip due to this State. It covers an area of 210.000 acres; and will be ready for delivery to the order of the State within thirty or forty days from the date of this communication. Further legislation on the part of the State is, however, necessary in the meantime to give a more formal acceptance of the grant in the terms of the Act of Congress. I recommend the enactment of a law for that purpose, and for the further purpose of authorizing the Governor to receive and receipt for the scrip and to convert it into money subject to the approval of the Lieut—Governor, the Attorney-General, and the Secretary of State, or a majority of these officers.
The proceeds of the land—scrip

due the State will amount, I presume, to about $160.000. In the act proposed for its acceptance and delivery I re-commend a provision to the effect that the money received for the scrip shall be invested at the discretion of the Governor, the Lieut—Governor, the Attorney—General, and the Secretary of State, a majority concurring, in the Bonds of the United States or of this State. The interest in the latter case would yield to the Southern University, under the distribution pro-posed, upwards of $7.500 a year. This annuity would maintain on a liberal scale the school of agri-culture and mechanic arts in each case; and any shortcomings remaining therefrom in reference to a model farm, a laboratory, and the mechanical appliances necessary to carry out the conditions of the grant in good faith, could be made ^good^ by special expenditures for four or five years from the proposed annuity of $50.000—.
An annuity of $50.000 in ^to^ each of the two Universities cannot

be justified on the basis of the working facts of the existing In-stitution. With 150 or 200 students, the severe arithmetic of free labor will very soon protest against even the ordinary grant to the college at Oxford.—Adam. Smith has raised his voice amongst us since the adoption of the fifteenth amend-ment.—To justify the large endowment I propose for the two establishments, and at the same time to commend them more broadly to the affections of the people, I propose to throw them open to the children of the poor by the system of free scholarships which I proposed ^have suggested^ in my annual message as referred to, as a prize for competition amongst the boys of our common schools. One white boy sent from each County annually to one University, and one colored boy sent annually ^from each county^ to the other University, we can maintain the number of students in each at from four to five hundred; and while reducing thus the average
cost to the State for each boy to one half the average cost now, we will have shielded our two great schools from that inexorable logic of our future political thinking—^that of^ public economy.

One hundred thousand dollars a year will certainly be a large ex-penditure upon our Universities. The number of young men to be thrown out in future into the society of the State at the level of scholar-ships must, however, be held by those who see the wisdom of elevating the negro to the intellectual condition of Liberty, to be double what it has been. And the Universities, to main-tain themselves as such in the judgment of the public, must be held, under the rivalry of that private study which is sure to follow from the universality of elementary knowledge, to demand all the resources necessary to their highest efficiency.
Elevated in the production of scholars to their proper height, those Institutions will exclude the

many Academics and Institutes that ^they^ would otherwise be brought into competition with ^at^ a waste of private means and of public income. While setting ^filling^ out the Universities to their proper dimensions, I would recommend earnestly that, to hold the preliminary training of their future students diffused amongst the masses of the people in the face of the danger threatening our ^an^ exhaustion of the school funds and the general opposition of the tax—payers, ^that^ you take such steps as, while preserving our common schools as a benfaction to all our people, shall place them under the restraints of an economy at once liberal and severe. Individual effort working on the basis of the general education must be looked to for the production of candidates for the University; but the production of those candidates maintained thus on a high and healthy basis, your legislation on the subject of public schools should, I submit ^suggest^ respectfully, never lose sight of the fact that the economy necessary to save the

school—system from ruin, goes forward properly in view of the fact that, those schools being designed primarily for the education of the great masses of a society of free labor, do not demand appliances of the character of walnut desks or teachers at the salaries approaching those of University professorors.

In dis-charging the duty of justice recommended in this message for a second time to your consideration, I may observe that there is no reason why we should set apart the new University formally for the people of color. Our under-standing of the present expediency which has lead us to accept the fact of the popular feeling ^which has been conciliated^ calculated in our action on separate schools will be sufficient to give peculiarity to the Southern University as it does by common consent to the Northern University. No legal barriers erected unnecessarily in either case, we may have ^allow^ distinctions of race to run their course in their proper character of social sentiments; and

thus permit an honorable rivalry in intellectual acquirement to grow up amongst the two sets of our population with free play for its operation in moderating all those forces of repulsion which may ^be held to^ originate in prejudice rather than in fact.
